Methods It was a cross-sectional survey carried out in May – Results In the study, among 1348 participants, 17.4% had ADL limitations, and 33.8% had IADL limitations. NL was negatively associated with limitations in ADL (OR: 0.97, 95% CI: 0.95 – – – Conclusion NL was negatively associated with physical function limitations in older adults, and the association varied by monthly income, education, and chronic disease status. Findings underscore that NL may be a promising intervention target to improve the physical function of older adults and interventions should be directed towards those with low levels of education and income, and chronic diseases. Demographic data indicate that older adults aged 60 and over accounted for 21.1% of the population by the end of 2023 in China [ 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 6 9 The main influencing factors for the limitations in ADL and IADL in older people can be summarized into several aspects. However, studies suggest that good eating habits and nutrient intake play significant roles in maintaining independence in ADL and IADL [ 10 11 13 14 15 16 17 Nutrition literacy (NL) is a new field of study, and its concept originates from health literacy. It is characterized in operational terms as the ability to acquire, process, and comprehend dietary knowledge and competencies, thereby enabling individuals to formulate optimal dietary decisions [ 18 19 20 18 21 22 21 23 24 25 26 Materials and methods Study design and participants A cross-sectional survey was carried out from May to July 2023 to explore the association between NL and health condition in Bengbu, China. A stratified cluster sampling was used to select participants. Inclusion criteria for the survey’s participants were being older than 18 years, and living in their community for at least 6 months prior to the survey. A self-designed structured questionnaire was used to collect data by interview. More details have been presented in previous study [ 27 A comprehensive survey was administered by community workers to a total of 2400 individuals. Out of the total participants, 2279 successfully completed the questionnaire, leading to an impressive completion rate of 95.0%. Given that ADL and IADL limitations are common among older adults, the study analyzed those aged ≥ 60 years. The initial study comprised 1355 participants, of which 7 cases (0.5%) underwent exclusion owing to incomplete datasets regarding NL, ADL, and IADL parameters. Ultimately, 1348 eligible subjects were retained for final analysis. Characteristics of the lost sample were found to be consistent with those of the final sample, with no significant differences. Sample size calculation The sample size was calculated using the formula: N Z 1−α/2 2 P P δ 2 P 4 δ P Nutrition literacy measurement The nutrition literacy-short form (NL-SF), adapted from the comprehensive 43-item NL assessment tool [ 28 29 27 Physical function limitations measurement Physical function limitations included ADL and IADL limitations. ADL were assessed based on the Katz Index [ 30 31 Covariates The subsequent sociodemographic information was gathered: gender (female, male), age (60–74 years old, 75–89 years old, 90 years old and above), marital status (married, others), education (primary school or below, secondary school and above), occupation (farmer, separated/retired staff and others), monthly income (< 1,000 RMB, 1,000–3,000 RMB, ≥ 3,000 RMB), drinking (never, former and current drinking), and smoking (never, former and current smoking). Place of residence included “urban areas” and “rural areas” based on the administrative division standards in China, i.e., districts or sub-districts (jiedao) in cities officially designated as urban areas, and townships (xiang) or villages (cun) officially designated as rural areas. Chronic disease status was acquired through the question “Do you have a physician-diagnosed chronic diseases listed below (hypertension, diabetes, heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, chronic lung disease, digestive system disorders, osteoporosis, abnormal blood lipids, arthritis, rheumatism or rheumatoid disorder, lumbar and back disorders, and cancer)?”. Response includes yes or no. Additionally, body mass index (BMI) was assessed using the following categories: underweight (< 18.5 kg/m 2 2 2 2 Statistical analysis The SPSS was employed for statistical analyses. Continuous variables were represented as mean ± standard deviation (SD) and categorical variables were represented as frequencies and percentages. Chi-square test was applied to compare differences in groups for categorical variables. Findings showed that approximately one-fifth of older adults have ADL limitations, one-third have IADL limitations, and a negative relationship was found between NL and ADL and IADL limitations. This suggests that physical function limitations become a public health issue in older people and enhancing NL might represent an effective approach for reducing the prevalence of ADL and IADL limitations. Our study showed that greater levels of NL were linked with lower rates of ADL and IADL limitations. NL is closely associated with individuals’ dietary habits and serves as a predictor of their dietary behaviors and quality. Consequently, this has a significant impact on the individual’s health [ 33 34 35 36 This study indicated a lack of association between nutritional knowledge and limitations in both ADL and IADL. This could be attributed to older adults accessing nutritional knowledge from non-professional sources (e.g., social media), which often contains inaccurate information [ 37 38 39 40 In this study, the inverse association of NL with ADL and IADL limitations was only observed in older adults with low education. This indicates that individuals with lower education attainment may improve their health management capabilities through practical learning, such as life experience [ 41 42 43 31 44 Among older individuals with a Monthly income of less than 1,000 yuan, NL is significantly and negatively correlated with physical function limitations. Low income hinders access to healthcare services and social resources [ 45 46 47 48 There are limitations in our study. First, as a cross-sectional survey, this research cannot establish causality regarding the association between NL and physical function limitations in older adults, and prospective longitudinal studies are needed to verify this relationship. Second, participants in this study were exclusively recruited from a specific geographical region in Bengbu, China, which may limit the generalizability of the findings. The elderly population in this region may have unique characteristics in terms of socioeconomic status, cultural factors, and health behaviors that are not representative of older adults in other regions of China or globally. Therefore, future research should endeavor to cover a diverse range of geographical regions and demographic groups to ascertain if these findings can be generalized to other populations. Third, the chronic disease categories included in this study are limited, and unassessed diseases may contribute to functional decline. Additionally, the assessment of the total number of chronic diseases in participants relied on self-reported data without verification of diagnostic details, which may result in an undercount or incomplete recording of comorbidities. Future research could employ more comprehensive chronic disease assessment methods, integrating medical records or clinical diagnoses. Finally, physical functional limitations rely primarily on self-reported information on ADL and IADL rather than objective measurements or clinical diagnoses. In such scenarios, older adults may choose to conceal their poor health and lifestyle habits, potentially impeding the accurate estimation of functional limitations and risking an underestimation. Future research needs to employ objective measures for assessing physical functional limitations. Conclusions NL showed a significant inverse association with physical function limitations in older adults, and this relationship appears to be influenced by factors such as education, income, and chronic disease. The findings suggest that NL may be a potential target for interventions aimed at improving physical function in older people. Moreover, policies or interventions targeting NL should consider differences in education, income, and chronic disease status. There is a need for increased focus on individuals with low education, low income, and chronic diseases.
